1975年，加州大学洛杉矶分校的精神病学家罗伯特·斯托勒(Robert Stoller)在他的教科书中写下了一些关于性和性别的离奇东西。他断言，那些出生时被认为是男孩，但性别身份或表情与这一假设不符的人“通常有漂亮的脸，有漂亮的头发，可爱的皮肤，优雅的动作，特别是--大而锐利的眼睛。”基于这一观察，他提出了一个理论模型，在这个模型中，变性人女孩变成变性人是因为她们特别可爱。他推断，社会对待她们更像是女孩，因为这段经历，她们开始认同为女性。
作为一名内科科学家，我一般认为知识会带来进步。但围绕这一特定问题的研究--那些询问是什么决定了一个人的性别认同的研究--引导我们走上了一些奇怪而危险的道路。这一领域的研究人员似乎在寻找一些客观事实，但这门科学植根于一个主观假设：我们需要知道是什么让一个人成为跨性别者，这样他们才能被“固定”。因此，科学家们不遗余力地追寻这样的问题，发起了一些研究，宣传可能会伤害变性人儿童及其家庭的想法。
斯托勒的观察激发了人们变性背后的许多心理学理论。1993年，多伦多克拉克精神病学研究所的一组研究人员着手测试他的假设，即美貌和当时被称为“性别认同障碍”的疾病是有联系的。他们招募了17名有诊断的出生分配男孩和17名没有诊断的出生分配男孩，他们都在8岁左右。研究人员随后拍摄了这些孩子的头部照片，并将其展示给36名大学生。学生们被要求给这些年轻人的外貌打分，从1分到5分，类别包括“有吸引力的”、“英俊的”和“漂亮的”。最终，大学生发现患有“性别认同障碍”的孩子比顺性男孩“更漂亮”。这些发现似乎表明斯托勒是对的：也许是因为他们的外表，人们把前一组中的年轻人更像女孩一样对待，结果他们变成了变性人。尽管如论文后面提到的，一个同样可信的理论是，这些孩子可能改变了他们的外表(长发等)，使大学生们将他们与更多的女性描述联系在一起，比如“漂亮”。
几年后，研究人员恢复了这一调查路线，使用了患有“性别认同障碍”的年轻出生分配女孩的头像。与顺性女孩相比，一群大学生再次对这些孩子的外表进行了“丑陋”或“漂亮”的评分。患有“性别认同障碍”的儿童被评为不那么漂亮，这促使研究人员提出，他们可能受到了更多的男孩对待，因此被认定为男性。似乎更有可能的是，这些孩子只是把头发剪短了，所以参与者给他们附加了更多的男性词汇。最后，这项研究并没有太多地揭示是什么让一个人成为变性人，但它确实促进了一种攻击性的理论，可能会削弱脆弱的变性人青年的自尊。
研究人员还研究了这些孩子的父母。长期以来，精神病学一直痴迷于母亲损害孩子发育的理论(例如，冰箱母亲理论假设自闭症是由于缺乏母亲的温暖所致)。这些研究同样询问是否父母应该为他们孩子的性别认同“负责”。在一篇论文中，研究人员评估了患有“性别认同障碍”儿童的母亲是否有更多的抑郁症状或一种称为边缘性人格障碍的疾病。他们发现这些母亲都有更多的这两种症状。听起来很有说服力，对吧？孩子们必须成为变性人，因为他们的母亲患有精神疾病。
研究人员没有讨论的是，母亲的症状很容易由社会对待孩子的方式引起。边缘型人格障碍的分量表较高的是“人际冲突”。即使你不是变性人孩子的父母，你也能想象在一个不被接受的社区里抚养你的孩子可能会造成实质性的冲突。
在另一项研究中，研究人员指出，患有“性别认同障碍”儿童的父母没有对刻板印象中的性别非典型行为施加强有力的限制，比如出生的男孩玩洋娃娃，出生的女孩玩积木或交通玩具。也许这就是“问题”的原因？作者推测，如果这些父母在早期就简单地打击这种行为-比方说，从他们蹒跚学步的孩子手中夺走芭比娃娃-他们可能已经阻止了这种行为。解释的可能性越大
这些关于性别认同起源的理论只会增加被误导的、越来越非法的呼吁，要求为变性人提供顺性别化的“疗法”。所谓性别认同转换疗法的逻辑是，如果环境是原因，那么我们可以简单地改变环境，将事情扼杀在萌芽状态。大多数“皈依”手册还没有向公众发布，但在2002年，哥伦比亚大学的一位心理学家出版了“年轻男孩中的性别认同障碍：基于父母和同伴的协议”，其中包括一些育儿技巧，如“母亲放过男孩”，强迫孩子与同性朋友玩耍，以及将青少年从体操或芭蕾舞等刻板印象中的非典型性别活动中剔除。值得注意的是，我和我的同事最近进行的一项研究表明，试图将儿童的性别身份从变性人改变为顺性人与自杀未遂的可能性更大相关。美国有几个州已经禁止转换疗法，但在美国大部分地区，这种做法仍在继续。
即使在今天，对变性人身份的心理原因的类似研究仍在继续。布朗大学(Brown University)的一位医生最近对通过网站招募的受访者进行了一项匿名调查，调查对象是那些认为同龄人压力和网络影响让他们的孩子变性人的父母。这项调查基本上是询问父母是否认为互联网让他们的孩子变性人，考虑到他们访问网站了解这个想法，父母们毫不奇怪地回答是的。保守派媒体抓住了这项研究，认为跨性别者儿童真的只是在Reddit上读到一些东西后被骗成为跨性别者的困惑的孩子。言下之意是，我们需要把这些孩子从支持LGBTQ的在线社区中带走，这样他们就可以再次成为顺性别。通读这些文献，我们需要问自己一些问题：为什么要进行这项研究？它希望实现什么目标？不知疲倦的寻找揭示了一个几乎不加掩饰的教条：变性人是一种有待修复的病理。这种信念不仅伤害了变性人，也破坏了好的科学。
好的科学告诉我们，当我们接纳变性人时，他们就会茁壮成长。我们不应该试图找出哪里出了问题，而应该把我们的时间和精力投入到倡导非歧视法律，增加获得医疗保健的机会，并在媒体上提高跨性别者的声音，这样社会才能意识到他们是我们社区的重要成员。当斯托勒注意到这些孩子是特殊的时候，也许他是对的。现在是我们庆祝并继续前进的时候了。

In 1975 psychiatrist Robert Stoller of the University of California, Los Angeles, wrote something bizarre in his  textbook on sex and gender. He asserted that people who were assumed to be boys when they were born but whose gender identity or expression did not match that assumption “often  have pretty faces, with fine hair, lovely complexions, graceful movements, and—especially—big, piercing, liquid eyes.”  Based on this observation, he suggested  a theoretical model in which transgender girls become transgender because they are especially cute. Society treats them more like girls, he reasoned, and because of this experience, they start to identify as female.
  As a physician-scientist, I’m generally of the opinion that knowledge leads to progress. But studies focused on this particular question—those asking what determines someone’s gender identity—have led us down some strange and dangerous paths. Researchers in this area appear to be in search of some objective truth, but the science is rooted in a subjective assumption: that we need to know what makes someone transgender so that they can be “fixed.” As a result, scientists have relentlessly pursued such questions, launching studies that promoted ideas that could hurt transgender children and their families.
  Stoller’s observations motivated many of the psychological theories behind what makes people transgender. In 1993 a group of researchers at the Clarke Institute of Psychiatry in Toronto  set out to test his hypothesis that beauty and what was then called “gender identity disorder”  were linked. They recruited 17 birth-assigned boys with the diagnosis and 17 birth-assigned boys without it ,  all around the age of eight. The researchers then took headshots of the children and showed them to 36 college students. The students were asked to rate the youngsters’ physical appearance on a scale from one to five with categories such as “attractive,” “handsome” and “beautiful.” In the end, the college students found the children with “gender identity disorder” to be “prettier” than the cisgender boys. The findings seem to suggest Stoller was right: perhaps, because of their appearance, people treated the youngsters in the former group more like girls, and consequently, they became transgender. Though as the authors mention later in the paper, an equally plausible theory is that these children could have altered their appearance (long hair, et cetera) in ways that matched their identity, leading the college students to associate them with more feminine descriptions such as “pretty.”
  A few years later, researchers  revived this line of investigation, using the headshots of young birth-assigned girls with “gender identity disorder.” A group of college students again rated how “ugly” or “pretty” these children appeared, compared with cisgender girls. The children with “gender identity disorder” were rated as less beautiful, prompting the researchers to suggest that they may have been treated more like boys and thus identified as male. It seems more likely that these children simply cut their hair shorter, so the participants attached more masculine words to them. In the end, the study didn’t reveal much about what makes someone transgender, but it did promote an offensive theory with the potential to diminish the self-esteem of vulnerable transgender youth.
  Researchers also studied the parents of such children. Psychiatry has long been enamored with the theory of mothers harming the development of their children (for example, the  refrigerator mother theory posited that autism was caused by a lack of maternal warmth). These studies similarly asked if perhaps parents were to “blame” for their kids’ gender identity. In one paper, researchers assessed whether  the mothers of children with “gender identity disorder” had more symptoms of either depression or a condition called borderline personality disorder. They found these mothers had more symptoms of both. Sounds convincing, right? Children must become transgender because their mothers are mentally ill.
  What the researchers failed to discuss was that the mothers’ symptoms could easily have been caused by the way society treated their children. The subscale of borderline personality disorder  that was higher among them was “interpersonal conflict.” You don’t need to be the parent of a transgender child to imagine that raising your kid in an unaccepting community could create substantial conflict.
  In another study, researchers noted that parents of children with “gender identity disorder” did not place strong limits on stereotypically gender atypical behaviors such as birth-assigned boys playing with dolls or birth-assigned girls playing with blocks or transportation toys. Perhaps this was the cause of the “problem”? If these parents had simply cracked down on this behavior early on—ripped the Barbie out of their toddler’s hands, say—they may have prevented it, the authors posited. The more likely explanation is that it’s difficult to take a doll away from a child who desperately wants to play with it. And that doing so makes them sad and impacts their self-esteem.
  In each case, researchers were hyperfocused on finding a problem with either the kids or their parents. But in the end, these scientists failed to establish one. They seemed less interested in a vital reframing: perhaps the issue was not the children’s identity but the way society treated them. Instead of supporting these kids, the researchers labeled them unattractive or painted their parents as mentally unstable.
  These theories on the origins of gender identity have only added to the misguided, and  increasingly illegal, calls for “therapies” designed to make transgender people cisgender. The logic of so-called gender identity conversion therapy is  that if the environment is the cause, then we can simply alter the environment to nip things in the bud. Most of the “conversion” manuals have not been released to the public, but in 2002 a psychologist at Columbia University published “ Gender Identity Disorder in Young Boys: A Parent and Peer-Based Protocol,” which included parenting techniques such as “letting go of [the] boy by [the] mother,”  forcing the child to play with same-sex friends, and removing the youngster from stereotypically gender-atypical activities such as gymnastics or ballet. Notably,  a recent study my colleagues and I conducted showed that attempts to change a child’s gender identity from transgender to cisgender are associated with greater odds of attempting suicide. Several U.S. states have banned conversion therapy, but in much of the U.S., these practices continue.
  Similar research into the psychological causes of transgender identity continues even today. A physician at Brown University recently conducted an anonymous survey of respondents recruited via Web sites for parents who believe peer pressure and online influences have made their children transgender.  The survey essentially asked the parents if they thought the Internet made their children trans, and the parents, not surprisingly, given that they were visiting Web sites about this idea, answered yes. Conservative media latched onto the study, suggesting that transgender children are really just confused kids tricked into being transgender after reading something on Reddit. The implication is that we need to take these kids away from supportive online LGBTQ communities so that they can be made cisgender again. Reading through this literature, we need to ask ourselves some questions: What is the reason for this research? What does it hope to accomplish? The tireless search reveals a thinly veiled dogma: that being transgender is a pathology to be fixed. This belief not only harms transgender people but also undermines good science.
  What good science shows us is that when we accept transgender people,  they thrive. Instead of trying to figure out what went “wrong,” we should be investing our time and energy into advocating for nondiscrimination laws, increasing access to health care and raising transgender voices in the media, so society realizes that they are vital members of our communities. Maybe Stoller was right when he noted that those children were exceptional. It’s time we celebrate that and move on.

梅多斯周日在接受美国有线电视新闻网(CNN)采访时说：“我们无法控制这场大流行。”相反，我们将把重点放在“疫苗、治疗和其他缓解领域”，他说。这些言论引发了广泛的轩然大波，梅多斯周一试图平息这场轩然大波。但他的澄清只会强化他早先的言论。
“我的意思是，当我们看到这一点时，我们将击败病毒。我们无法控制它。我们将尽最大努力遏制它，“他昨天在白宫外对记者表示。他再次强调了治疗和疫苗的必要性。
在世卫组织周一的新闻发布会上，世卫组织总干事Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus直言不讳地说：“放弃控制是危险的。”
虽然Ghebreyesus同意治疗学和疫苗的重要性，但他指出，到目前为止，它们还没有推出。因此，“控制也应该是战略的一部分，”他说。“政府应该尽到自己的一份力量，公民也应该尽到自己的一份力量。否则，这种病毒是危险的。如果放任不管，可能会造成严重破坏。“
note_en:
Top officials at the World Health Organization on Monday appeared at times exasperated, flabbergasted, and wearied as they confronted comments by White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows suggesting that the United States has given up trying to control the spread of the pandemic coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2.
 “We’re not going to control the pandemic,” Meadows said in  a CNN interview Sunday. Instead we will focus on “vaccines, therapeutics, and other mitigation areas,” he said. The comments spurred widespread uproar, which Meadows tried to quell Monday. But his clarification only reinforced his earlier comments.
 “I mean, when we look at this, we’re going to defeat the virus. We’re not going to control it. We will try to contain it as best we can,”  he told reporters outside the White House yesterday. He again emphasized the need for therapeutics and vaccines.
  In a WHO press briefing Monday, WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus spoke bluntly: “ Giving up on control is dangerous.”
 While Ghebreyesus agreed on the importance of therapeutics and a vaccine, he noted that so far, they are not yet available. As such, “control should also be part of the strategy,” he said. “The government should do its share and the citizens also should do their share. Otherwise, this virus is dangerous. If it’s let go freely, it can create havoc.”

斯塔克计划利用这笔资金继续将集成构建到常用的设计应用程序中，并为开发人员创建集成(它将阅读代码并提供指导：Next Up是Github集成)，并继续通过扩大定价范围和使用层级来构建业务。
目前，用户可以使用Stark on Figma、Sketch&amp；Adobe XD插件访问对比度检查器、智能颜色建议、8色盲模拟、色盲生成器和快速对比度检查(在Adobe XD上)。
从长远来看，我们的计划是建立端到端的平台，并解决视觉障碍以外的其他类型需求的包容性问题，而且，由于无障碍也可以以物理形式出现，因此考虑的不仅仅是软件，并创造更多的方法来自动更正细节。
现居欧洲的首席执行官凯特·努恩(Cat Noone)与迈克尔·福凯(Michael Fuquet)共同创立了这家公司(她说，团队正在远程工作)。正如她所描述的那样，公司的雄心是“成为软件可访问性方面的格莱马利”(Grammarly For Accessibility In Software)。
这笔资金是种子期前的一轮融资，来自广泛而有趣的支持者群体。它由Darling Ventures和Indicator Ventures的丹尼尔·达林(Daniel Darling)和帕斯卡·昂格(Pascal Unger)共同领导，Github的首席技术官杰森·华纳(Jason Warner)、凯鹏华盈的童子军基金(Kleiner Perkins‘Scout Fund)和Basecamp Ventures也参与其中。个人资助者包括Atlassian的无障碍产品主管，Culture amp的公平设计和影响总监，DuckDuckGo的设计总监，甲骨文的前软件开发副总裁，等等。
斯塔克之所以获得所有这些投资者的关注，部分原因是它的吸引力。
该软件的早期版本已经以Sketch、Adobe XD和Figma插件的形式发布了8个月，在此期间它已经积累了30万用户，其中大部分是这三个设计平台的设计师、工程师和产品经理，目前的客户包括来自微软、奥斯卡健康、美国银行、Instagram、辉瑞、大众、Dropbox等等的人。
它的“社区”也有10000人，其中包括更直接地(而不是仅仅使用它的插件)与Stark互动的人，在Slake这样的平台上，获取它的时事通讯等等。
多样性和包容性成为今年的头条新闻，这是个好消息，尽管原因并不是那么好-执法部门对待少数族裔的令人遗憾的状况。在一定程度上，由于这些事件和随后的抗议活动的概况，世界上很多地方都将D&Amp；i的概念与种族包容紧密联系在一起。虽然这个故事还在继续展开(我们希望继续看到更积极和持续的努力来解决这个问题)，但斯塔克正在解决的那种多样性和包容性是不同类型的。
这是一个合乎逻辑的领域，尽管经常被忽视：疾病控制和预防中心估计(截至2018年)，仅美国就有大约四分之一的成年人患有某种形式的残疾(这个数字不包括儿童)，其中最大的残疾是认知障碍。这本质上意味着，虽然很多设计(和技术总体上)并不是真正针对这一更广泛的群体而设计的，但这是一个非常大的市场。
在科技经常被认为是坏人的时候-原因很多，涉及心理健康；身体健康；以及经济、环境、民事和法律影响-设计更具包容性的软件和硬件，可能会在弥合科技与社会(以及社会内部)造成的一些鸿沟方面大有裨益。
“我们谈论的是美国最大的少数群体，”Noone说。“如果没有轮椅坡道，你今天就不会建造一座大楼，那么我们为什么不在软件设计中考虑到这些人呢？”
努恩说，她和福凯最初是在为另一家公司工作时产生了斯塔克的想法，当时他们正在为另一家公司开发一款供老年人使用的紧急服务应用程序。他们构建了一个非常早期的工具版本，供自己在那项工作中使用。当他们把它展示给其他人看时，他们发现有人问他们是否也可以使用它。“然后就像滚雪球一样，”她说。
然后她说，她发现自己陷入了一个“设计和可访问性的世界的兔子洞”，并意识到不仅没有真正制造的工具来解决这个问题，而且“除了颜色之外，问题还有很多”。(颜色是斯塔克开始的地方，因此才有了这个伟大的名字。)。
在更大的市场上，像包容性设计这样的东西有一个有趣的大棒和胡萝卜：对一些人来说，这可能是一个必须遵守的问题，另一些人只是认为这是正确的事情，而另一些人可能不在乎，但(相当愤世嫉俗地)认为包容性是一个很好的外观。不管动机是什么，斯塔克的诀窍在于，它让更多的人更容易做到包容，最终降低门槛只能是一件好事。
“任何软件产品都不应排斥其用户中的少数弱势群体。这不利于商业，也不利于社会，“达林在一份声明中说。我们看到，软件设计者、开发人员和管理人员对发运全球通用产品的意识正在急剧提高。斯塔克很快赢得了业界的信任，并正走上成为软件基础设施重要组成部分的道路。我们很高兴能与这样一家使命驱动的公司合作，它已经在改善世界各地的软件生产方式。“​
note_en:
Stark, a New York-based startup that lets designers others building with design software run their files through an integrated tool that checks it and provides color edits and other suggestions to help them meet guidelines for people who see less well, has picked up $1.5 million.
 Stark plans to use the funding to continue building integrations into commonly-used design apps and create integrations for developers (where it will read and provide guidance on code: next up is a Github integration), and continue building out its business with  expanded pricing and usage tiers.
  Currently, users can use plugins of Stark on Figma, Sketch & Adobe XD that let them access a Contrast Checker, Smart Color Suggestions, 8 Colorblind Simulations, a Colorblind Generator, and Rapid Contrast Checking (on Adobe XD).
 Longer term, the plan is to build and end-to-end platform and to address inclusivity for other kinds of needs beyond visual impairments, and, since accessibility can come in physical forms, too, to consider more than just software, and to create more ways to automatically correct details.
 As Cat Noone — the now-European-based CEO who co-founded the company with Michael Fouquet (the team is working remotely, she said) — describes it, the ambition is to “become the Grammarly for accessibility in software.”
  The funding, a pre-seed round, is coming from a wide and interesting group of backers. It was co-led by Daniel Darling and Pascal Unger from Darling Ventures and Indicator Ventures; with participation also from Jason Warner, the CTO of Github; Kleiner Perkins’ Scout Fund; and Basecamp Ventures. Individual backers include the product lead for accessibility at Atlassian, the director of equitable design & impact at Culture Amp, a director of design at DuckDuckGo, a former VP of software development at Oracle, and more.
 Part of the reason that Stark has gotten attention from all of these investors is because of its traction.
 Early versions of the software have been out for eight months now, in the form of the plugins for Sketch, Adobe XD and Figma, and in that time it’s clocked up 300,000 users, mostly designers, engineers, and product managers across those three design platforms, with current customers including people from Microsoft, Oscar Health, US Bank, Instagram, Pfizer, Volkswagen, Dropbox and more.
 It also has 10,000 people in its “community”, which includes people engaging with Stark more directly (rather than just using its plugins), on platforms like Slack, getting its newsletter and more.
 Diversity and inclusion have been in the headlines this year, which is good news, even if the reason for it has been not so good — the sorry state of how minorities are treated by law enforcement. Partly because of the profile of those incidents and the subsequent protests, much of the world has associated the concept of D&I very closely with racial inclusion. While that story continues to unfold (and we hopefully continue see more positive and sustained efforts to address it), the kind of diversity and inclusion Stark is addressing is of a different sort.
 It’s a logical, if often overlooked area: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention  estimate that (as of 2018) around one in every four adults in the U.S. alone live with some form of disability (a figure that doesn’t count children), with the biggest of these being cognitive disabilities. This essentially means that while a lot of design (and tech in general) is not really built to address this wider group, it’s a very sizable market.
 At a time when technology is regularly made out to be the bad guy — and the reasons are many, touching on mental health; physical health; and economic, environmental, civil and legal impacts — designing software and hardware that is more inclusive could go a very long way in bridging some of those gaps that tech has created with (and within) society.
 “We’re talking about the largest minority group in the U.S.,” Noone said. “You wouldn’t build a building today without a wheelchair ramp, so why aren’t we accounting for those individuals in our software design?”
 Noone said that she and Fouquet originally landed on the idea of Stark when they were doing some work for another firm, building an emergency services app that would get used by the elderly. They built a very early version of the tool for themselves to use in that work. Showing it to others, they found people asking if they could use it, too. “And then it just kind of snowballed,” she said.
 She then said that she found herself going down a “rabbit hole into the world of design and accessibility” and realised that not only were there no tools really built to address this out there, but that there was “so much more to the problem than colors.” (Colors was where Stark started, hence the great name.)
 There is an interesting stick and carrot in the bigger market with things like inclusive design: for some it might be an issue of having to comply, others simply believe it’s the right thing to do, while yet others may not care but (rather cynically) believe being inclusive is a good look. Whatever the motivation is, the trick with Stark is that it’s making it easy to be inclusive for more people, and lowering the barrier at the end of the day can only be a good thing.
 “No software product should exclude a disadvantaged minority of their users. It’s bad for business and bad for society,” said Darling in a statement. “We’re seeing dramatic increasing awareness amongst software designers, developers and executives to ship products that are universally accessible. Stark has quickly earned the trust of the industry and is on a path to become an important part of software infrastructure. We’re thrilled to partner with such a mission driven company that is already improving how software is produced around the world.”​

title: 5篇将改变本世纪20年代的创业论文
title_en: 5 startup theses that will transform the 2020s

note:
每个人都沉着地报道了2010年代的结束，这十年，至少在科技业，充满了巨大的里程碑，包括一些有史以来规模最大的初创公司IPO，也包括一些我们见过的最糟糕的低点-欺诈和产品混乱，规模和规模比以往任何时候都要大。
不过，这些回顾本应与展望相辅相成--本世纪20年代将会发生什么？下一个是什么？这十年的进步和创新将来自哪里？当然，在大流行来袭之前，我们刚刚度过了这十年，美国大选进入了全面展开的阶段，关于学校开学、竞选演讲以及疫苗是否会很快、很快、遥远地到来，或者我猜永远不会到来的辩论一直在不停地进行。
我们的集体长期愿景已经被不断在我们的馈送中滚动的短期新闻吓坏了。是时候改变这一点了。
不管下周(或者下个月)结果如何？在美国或新冠肺炎的最终疫苗时间表上，我们仍然需要定义下一个十年是关于什么的，特别是在技术领域，问题清单正在扩大，具有创新潜力的行业数量也在扩大。我们需要超越初创企业和融资的平凡日常运营挑战，考虑我们希望在未来几年赋予和传播的价值观。
这些问题中的许多不仅仅是“应用程序”，还包括法律、文化、社会以及最终我们想要留给我们所有人身后的下一代的领域。
在EC上，我写了一篇深度文章，深入探讨了五大变革“集群”，它们有可能在本世纪20年代改变我们的世界，在“健康”、“气候”、“数据社会”、“创造力”和“基础”等领域，每个领域都拥有如此多的创业想法，以至于我真的对这十年将要释放的东西感到兴奋。
然而，无论你是否喜欢我的无定形分组，我鼓励创业生态系统中的每个人开始思考如何将不同的创业公司、不同的行业以及我们的社会是如何组织起来的。下一代创业点子不会来自广为人知的白板和Xcode中的一些SWIFT工程。它们将来自于对我们的社会和我们所有人未来需要什么的更有条理、更深入的反思。
2010年代的重点是实现移动、云和基础数据的梦想。这些想法在某些情况下可以追溯到几十年甚至更长时间(例如，万尼瓦尔·布什对互联网的描述可以追溯到20世纪40年代)。但这是第一次，我们拥有了基础设施和用户来实际构建这些产品，并使它们变得有用。这很可能是科技史上最广泛的绿地机会。
然而，这片绿地正在日益休耕。商业和媒体报道一样具有周期性和季节性。简单的事情已经做完了。开发一款给人发短信的应用程序之前已经有几十个人完成了。有大量的分析软件包、工资提供程序、信用卡发行商等等。这十年需要的是开始涉及更棘手的问题，比如我们如何建设一个更好的社会，让人们更有能力做深入和创造性的工作，以及我们如何为所有人建立一个更具弹性和可持续发展的地球。
这些话题都没有纯粹的点解决方案--但这就是让未来十年变得如此有趣的原因。这将需要密切的合作，多种发明和产品，以及法律和文化变革，才能实现这些下一步的改进。如果你现在已经厌倦了最新的应用程序和SaaS产品(就像我一样)，那么这十年将是一个值得体验和打造的令人惊叹的十年。
这是一个新的赛季，我们应该抬起头来环顾四周。是的，这个世界充满了问题--可怕的、可怕的、令人生厌的问题，这些问题有时会让人觉得几乎无法克服。但人类的聪明才智总能找到一种方法，我们从未有过如此广泛的工具箱来同时面对所有这些问题。如果说2010年代完全是关于人类学习技术的，那么2020年代完全是关于技术学习关于人类的。
note_en:
Everyone covered the end of the 2010s with aplomb, a decade that, at least in tech, was filled with huge milestones, including some of the largest startup IPOs of all time and also some of the worst lows we’ve ever seen — frauds and product snafus that were larger and grander than ever before.
 Those retrospectives though were supposed to be complemented with the prospectives — what’s about to happen in the 2020s? What’s next? Where is progress and innovation going to come from this decade? We barely got this decade going of course before the pandemic hit, the U.S. elections got into full swing, and it has been non-stop debates about school openings, stump speeches, and whether a vaccine will arrive soon, shortly, distantly, or I guess never at all.
  Our collective long-term vision has been terrorized by the short-term news that constantly rolls through our feeds. It’s time to change that.
 Regardless of the outcome next week (or maybe next month?) in the U.S. or the final vaccine timeline for COVID-19, we still need to define what this next decade is about, particularly in technology, where the list of issues is widening and the number of sectors that have the potential for innovation expands. We need to think beyond the mundane daily operational challenges of startups and fundraises and consider the values we want to empower and inform in the years ahead.
 Many of these questions go beyond mere “apps” to encompass areas of law, culture, societies, and ultimately, what we want to leave for the next generations coming behind all of us.
 Over on EC,  I’ve written a deep dive into five broad “clusters” of change that have the potential to transform our world in the 2020s, in areas like “wellness,” “climate,” “data society,” “creativity,” and “fundamentals” that each hold so many startups ideas that I truly am excited about what’s about to be unleashed this decade.
  Yet, whether you like my amorphous groupings or not, I encourage everyone in the startup ecosystem to begin thinking about how to connect the dots between different startups, different sectors, and how our society is organized. The next generation of startup ideas are not going to come from the proverbial whiteboard and some Swift engineering in Xcode. They’re going to come from much more methodical and deeper introspection about what our society and all of us need going forward.
 The 2010s were all about executing on the dreams of mobile, cloud, and basic data. Those ideas had historical antecedents going back in some cases decades or more (Vannevar Bush’s description of the internet dates to the 1940s, for instance). But for the first time, we had the infrastructure and the users to actually build these products and make them useful. It was quite possibly the most extensive greenfield opportunity in the history of technology.
 Yet, that greenfield is increasingly fallow. Business has cycles and seasonality as much as media reporting does. The easy stuff has been done. Building an app to text people has been done by dozens before. There are a multitude of analytics packages, and payroll providers, and credit card issuers, and more. What’s required this decade is to start to encroach on the harder questions, topics like how we build a better society, make people more empowered to do deep and creative work, and how we can build a more resilient and sustainable planet for all.
 None of these topics have pure point solutions — but that is what is going to make this coming decade so damn interesting. It’s going to take intense collaboration, multiple inventions and products, as well as legal and cultural changes, to realize these next improvements. If you have grown sick (as I have) of the latest apps and SaaS products du jour, this decade is going to be an amazing one to experience and build.
 It’s a new season to lift our heads up a little and look around. The world, yes, is filled with problems — terrible, horrible, and stultifying problems that can at times feel all but insurmountable. But human ingenuity has always found a way, and we have never had such an extensive toolbox to confront all of them simultaneously. If the 2010s were all about humans learning technology, the 2020s is all about technology learning about humans.

The change, the company explains, is meant to help those who’ve had to pivot to virtual events, like yoga and fitness instructors, teachers, musicians, artists and activists, among others. During the height of government lockdowns in the U.S., Instagram Live became a place for people to gather as  DJ’s hosted  live sets ,  artists played their music for fans,  celebs hosted live talk shows,  workout enthusiasts joined live classes, and more. Live usage  had then jumped 70% over pre-coronavirus numbers in the U.S. as people connected online.
 Many of these Instagram Live creators had wanted to extend their sessions beyond the 60 minute time limit without an interruption.
  The change puts Instagram on par with  the time limits offered by Facebook for live streams from mobile devices, which is also 4 hours. (If live streaming from a desktop computer or via an API, the Facebook time limit expands to 8 hours.)
 While the longer time limit is opening up to all creators worldwide starting today, Instagram says the creator’s account has to be “good standing” in order to take advantage. That means the account can’t have a history of either intellectual property or policy violations.
 Related to this change, Instagram will also update the “Live Now” section in IGTV and at the end of live streams to help direct users to more live content.
  It says that it will “soon” add an option that will allow creators to archive their live streams for up to 30 days.
  Before, users could archive their Feed posts or their Stories to a private archive, but the only way to save a live stream was to publish it to IGTV immediately after the stream, through  a feature introduced in May.
 The company says the new option to archive live broadcasts will mirror the existing archive experience for Stories and Feed Posts.
  But up until that time, the creator has the option to return to the video to save it or download it. This would allow the creator to publish the video on other social platforms, like Facebook or YouTube, or even trim out key parts for short-form video platforms, like TikTok. The Archive feature also means if a creator’s Live stream crashes for some reason — or if the creator forgot to download it in the moment — it can still be downloaded later on.

正在美国付费电视领域发起新一轮攻势，有可能进一步扰乱市场动态：该运营商宣布推出一套新的TVision互联网套餐，在全国范围内提供，起价仅为每月10美元。
通过这部新的夸张电视剧，T-Mobile希望吸引剪线公司-同时挖走受够了传统付费电视高昂价格和限制性频道包装的现有有线和卫星电视客户。TVision服务可以在家中使用，也可以在美国任何地方的无线应用程序上使用。
T-Mobile还推出了TVision Hub，这是一款售价50美元的基于Android电视的适配器(带遥控器)，可以插入高清电视的背面，提供对TVision OTT服务和包括Netflix和YouTube在内的8000多个应用程序的访问。
T-Mobile首席执行官迈克·西弗特(Mike Sievert)在宣布TVision阵容的直播中表示：“人们当然喜欢电视，但他们肯定不喜欢他们的电视提供商。”他说，现有的有线和卫星电视提供商将客户扣为“人质”，因为他们“将直播新闻和体育与数百个你不想要的其他频道捆绑在一起”。
新的TVision服务可以在iOS、Android(和Android TV)、亚马逊Fire TV和Apple TV等平台上使用。OTT套餐和TVision Hub计划从11月1日开始上市，首先是T-Mobile后付费无线用户。11月晚些时候，TVision将向传统的Sprint客户推出。2021年，T-Mobile计划向预付费无线客户和没有T-Mobile的客户提供OTT服务。
入门级Vibe(10美元/月)。提供30个非体育/非新闻频道，如AMC、BET、喜剧中心、探索、美食网络、HGTV、MTV和TLC，并有两个并发流。三个“直播”电视套餐，包括100个小时的DVR录制和最多三个流，分别是：TVision Live TV(40美元/月)。有30多家体育、新闻和地方电视台，包括迪士尼、ESPN、ABC、福克斯、NBC、CNN/Turner；Live TV Plus(50美元/月)，增加了NFL网络和其他体育网络；Live Zone(60美元/月)，增加了NFL RedZone和其他几个网站。
T-Mobile还提供了一系列TVision频道，包括Showtime(10.99美元/月)、Starz(8.99美元/月)。和Epix(5.99美元/月)，可以单独购买，也可以与其他电视捆绑包一起购买。
T-Mobile娱乐公司高级副总裁罗伯特·加里(Robert Gary)表示：“这是我们认为可以提供的最大限度的选择。”
到12月31日，T-Mobile将向参加两个最昂贵的TVision计划(Live TV Plus或Live Zone)之一的用户免费使用Apple TV Plus 12个月，并提供Apple TV 4K机顶盒折扣(扣除折扣后为99美元，通常为179美元)。
总体而言，T-Mobile新的TVision服务最根本的变化是，它将娱乐和生活方式频道拆分成单独的Vibe套餐，新闻、体育和地方电视在“直播”层。但这也意味着，如果你想要一个完整的有线电视阵容，你仍然需要支付与传统付费电视提供商或互联网OTT电视服务(如YouTube TV或Hulu with Live TV)相当的价格。
值得注意的是，TVision Live阵容没有哥伦比亚广播公司(CBS)的广播网络，T-Mobile也没有提供HBO或HBO Max(AT&amp；T‘s WarnerMedia的一部分)作为点菜选项。该运营商的OTT服务目前也不能在Roku设备上使用。
关于产品中没有CBS本地电视台，Gary表示，客户可以独立于TVision订阅CBS All Access(2021年将更名为派拉蒙Plus)。他说：“那些想要CBS的完整体验的人可以每月5.99美元获得，所以他们有这个选择。”Gary补充说，美国电话电报公司希望在未来增加对TVision的Roku支持，并可能考虑探索将HBO Max纳入阵容。
该公司将TVision的重新推出吹捧为其最新的“非运营商”举措-T-Mobile的尖刻营销口号，用来抨击其规模更大的竞争对手AT&amp；T和Verizon。
事实上，T-Mobile的低价TVision服务最直接针对的是美国电话电报公司(AT&amp；T)--该公司的付费电视业务在过去两年里大幅缩水。第三季度，AT&amp；T的“付费电视”用户(DirecTV和AT&amp；T TV宽带服务)总计1710万，过去12个月亏损330万。AT&amp；T TV Now，该电信公司的OTT服务，本应抵消这些损失，但现在缩减到68.3万人(同比下降40%)。
新的TVision服务基于T-Mobile于2017年收购的初创公司Layer3开发的技术。该运营商将重新换皮的TVision Home服务宣传为“有线电视的另一种选择”-但由于起步价为每月100美元，对剪线者来说并不具吸引力。此外，Layer3的模式是通过与可以保证吞吐量的宽带提供商达成协议来提供付费电视；现有的TVision Home在芝加哥、达拉斯-沃斯堡、洛杉矶、纽约市、费城、旧金山、华盛顿特区和科罗拉多州朗蒙特等大都市地区的供应有限。相比之下，新的TVision OTT电视服务可以在任何宽带服务上工作。
T-Mobile此前曾通过其狂欢计划迎合流媒体视频用户，为无线客户提供无限制的合作伙伴服务。2017年，西弗特指出，这一直是T-Mobile最受欢迎的客户福利之一，该公司增加了“Netflix on us”，向T-Mobile无限家庭计划的客户提供Netflix，不收取额外费用。

is taking an aggressive new swing at the U.S. pay-TV sector, threatening to further roil the market’s dynamics: The carrier announced a new suite of TVision internet packages, available nationwide, that start at just $10 per month.
 With the new over-the-top TV play, T-Mobile wants to attract cord-cutters — and also poach existing cable and satellite TV customers who are fed up with traditional pay TV’s high prices and restrictive channel packaging. The TVision services are available in-home and also on wireless apps anywhere in the U.S.
 T-Mobile also is introducing TVision Hub, a $50  Android TV-based adapter (with a remote) that plugs into the back of an HDTV to provide access to the TVision OTT services and 8,000-plus apps including Netflix and YouTube.
  “People sure love TV — but they sure don’t love their TV provider,” T-Mobile CEO Mike Sievert said in livestream announcing the TVision lineup. He said incumbent cable and satellite TV providers are holding customers “hostage,” because they bundle in “live news and sports with hundreds of other channels you don’t want.”
   The new TVision services are available on platforms including iOS, Android (and Android TV), Amazon Fire TV and Apple TV. The OTT packages and the TVision Hub are scheduled to be available starting Nov. 1, starting first with T-Mobile postpaid wireless subscribers. Later in November, TVision will be available to legacy Sprint customers. In 2021, T-Mobile plans to offer the OTT services to prepaid wireless customers and those who don’t have T-Mobile as well.
 The entry-level Vibe ($10/mo.) features 30 non-sports/non-news channels like AMC, BET, Comedy Central, Discovery, Food Network, HGTV, MTV and TLC, with two concurrent streams. The three “live” TV packages, which include 100 hours of DVR recording and up to three streams, are: TVision Live TV ($40/mo.) with 30-plus sports, news and local TV stations including from Disney, ESPN, ABC, Fox, NBC, CNN/Turner; Live TV Plus ($50/mo.), which adds NFL Network and other sports nets; and Live Zone ($60/mo.), which adds NFL RedZone and a handful of others.
  T-Mobile also is offering a selection of TVision Channels — with options for Showtime ($10.99/mo.), Starz ($8.99/mo.) and Epix ($5.99/mo.), available as standalone packages or with other the TV bundles.
  “It’s maximizing choice where we think we can offer it,” said Robert Gary, senior VP of T-Mobile Entertainment.
 Through Dec. 31, T-Mobile will give subs who take one of the two priciest TVision plans (Live TV Plus or Live Zone) free access to Apple TV Plus for 12 months and a discounted Apple TV 4K set-top ($99 after rebate; it’s normally $179).
 Overall, the most radical change with T-Mobile’s new TVision services is that it splits entertainment and lifestyle channels into the separate Vibe package, with news, sports and local TV in the “live” tiers. But that also means that if you want a complete cable TV lineup, you’re still going to pay rates comparable to traditional pay-TV providers or internet OTT TV services like YouTube TV or Hulu With Live TV.
  Notably, the TVision Live lineups are missing CBS broadcast networks, and T-Mobile does not offer HBO or HBO Max — part of AT&T’s WarnerMedia — as an a-la-carte option. The carrier’s OTT services also are not available on Roku devices at this point.
 Regarding the absence of CBS local stations in the product, Gary said customers are able to subscribe to CBS All Access (which will be rebranded Paramount Plus in 2021) separately from TVision. “Those who want that full CBS experience can get it for $5.99 per month, and so they have that choice,” he said. T-Mobile is looking to add Roku support for TVision in the future, Gary added, and may consider exploring bringing HBO Max into the lineup.
 The company touted the TVision relaunch as its latest “Un-carrier” move — T-Mobile’s snarky marketing tagline that it uses to diss its bigger rivals, AT&T and Verizon.
 Indeed, T-Mobile’s low-priced TVision offerings are aimed most directly at AT&T — whose pay-TV rolls have crumbled dramatically over the last two years. For the third quarter, AT&T’s “premium TV” subscribers (DirecTV and AT&T TV broadband service) totaled 17.1 million, a loss of 3.3 million over the past 12 months. AT&T TV Now, the telco’s OTT service that was supposed to offset such losses, shrank to 683,000 (down 40% year-over-year).
 The new TVision services are based on technology developed by  startup Layer3, which T-Mobile bought in 2017. The carrier  promoted the reskinned TVision Home service as “an alternative to cable TV” — but with a starting price of $100 per month, it wasn’t appealing to cord-cutters. In addition, Layer3’s model was to deliver pay TV through deals with broadband providers who could guarantee throughput; the existing TVision Home has had limited availability, in metro areas including Chicago, Dallas-Fort Worth, Los Angeles, New York City, Philadelphia, San Francisco, Washington, D.C., and Longmont, Colo. By contrast, the new TVision OTT television services work over any broadband service.
 T-Mobile has previously catered to streaming-video users with its Binge On program, offering wireless customers unlimited access to partner services. In 2017, in what Sievert noted has been one of T-Mobile’s most popular customer perks,  the company added “Netflix On Us,” providing Netflix for no extra charge to customers on T-Mobile unlimited family plans.

华盛顿(路透社)-美国联邦通信委员会(Federal Communications Commission)周二以3票赞成、2票反对的结果，维持2017年废除奥巴马时代的网络中立规则，尽管一家联邦法院指示对该废除的一些条款进行审查。
2015年的网络中立规则禁止互联网服务提供商(ISP)屏蔽或减缓互联网内容，或提供付费“快速通道”。在唐纳德·特朗普(Donald Trump)总统的领导下，2017年联邦通信委员会(FCC)的命令授予互联网服务提供商广泛的权力，只要他们披露变化，就可以重塑美国人使用互联网的方式。
2019年10月，一家联邦上诉法院在很大程度上维持了FCC对这些规定的废除，但命令该机构重新考虑废除对公共安全的影响；关于附连电线杆的规定；以及FCC为宽带服务提供补贴的能力。FCC的多数人选择保持订单不变。
网络中立废除于2018年6月生效。互联网服务提供商没有改变用户访问互联网的方式，但消费者团体担心，他们可能会有选择地为一些客户提高价格或降低网速。
FCC主席阿吉特·派(Ajit Pai)周二表示：“除了最忠诚的网络中立邪教成员外，所有人都清楚地看到，反对(网络中立废除)的案件是一个骗局。”
互联网服务提供商和其他网络中立废除的倡导者表示，新规则促进了投资。消费者团体和其他对这场争论持批评态度的人断言，放松网络中立规则会带来新的投资。
FCC委员、民主党人杰西卡·罗森沃塞尔(Jessica Rosenworcel)说：“这个机构对正确的做法不感兴趣。相反，它加倍努力，而不是承认我们周围世界的现实。“。
民主党人已经将网络中立作为竞选议题之一。总统候选人、奥巴马的副总统乔·拜登(Joe Biden)预计，如果他获胜，将任命一名FCC主席，这名主席将恢复网络中立。
民主党参议员埃德·马基(Ed Markey)表示：“如果没有网络中立保护，大型宽带提供商开始提高价格，减缓网速，并使家庭、小企业和学生更难获得从这场流行病中恢复和重建的机会，这只是个时间问题。”

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The U.S. Federal Communications Commission voted 3-2 on Tuesday to maintain its 2017 repeal of Obama-era net neutrality rules, even after a federal court directed a review of some provisions of the repeal.
 The 2015 net neutrality rules barred internet service providers (ISPs) from blocking or slowing internet content or offering paid “fast lanes.” Under President Donald Trump, the 2017 FCC order granted ISPs sweeping powers to recast how Americans use the internet, as long as they disclose changes.
 A federal appeals court in October 2019 largely upheld the FCC’s repeal of the rules, but ordered the agency to reconsider the repeal’s impact on public safety; regulations on attachments to utility poles; and the FCC’s ability to provide subsidies for broadband service. The FCC majority opted to leave the order unchanged.
  The net neutrality repeal was effective in June 2018. ISPs have not changed how users access the internet, but consumer groups fear that they could move to raise prices or slow speeds selectively for some customers.
 “It is patently obvious to all but the most devoted members of the net neutrality cult that the case against the (net neutrality repeal) was a sham,” FCC Chairman Ajit Pai said Tuesday.
 ISPs and other advocates of the net neutrality repeal say the new rules have boosted investment. Consumer groups and other critics of the dispute the assertion that loosening net neutrality rules led to new investment.
  FCC Commissioner Jessica Rosenworcel, a Democrat, said “this agency is not interested in getting it right. Instead, it doubles down, rather than recognizing the realities of the world around us.”
 Democrats have made net neutrality repeal a campaign issue. Presidential candidate Joe Biden, who was Obama’s vice president, is expected if he wins to designate an FCC chair who would move to would reinstate net neutrality.
 Senator Ed Markey, a Democrat, said “without net neutrality protections, it’s just a matter of time before big broadband providers start raising prices, slowing down internet speeds, and making it harder for families, small business, and students to access the opportunities to recover and rebuild from this pandemic.”

Fire已经完成了由红杉资本(Sequoia Capital)牵头的1.7亿美元的E系列融资，将这家在线批发商的估值提高了一倍多，达到25亿美元。这家总部位于旧金山的初创公司通过帮助小企业囤积需求旺盛的商品，从大流行购物模式中获利。
彭博社(Bloomberg)上周最先报道了这轮融资，称该公司正在洽谈以超过20亿美元的估值筹集超过1亿美元的资金。包括Y Combinator、LightSpeed Venture Partners、Forerunner Ventures、Khosla Ventures和Founders Fund在内的现有投资者参加了这轮融资，新投资者DST Global、D1 Capital Partners、Norwest Venture Partners和Dragoneer也加入了这轮融资。自2017年成立以来，Fire总共筹集了4.39亿美元。
批发市场是由三名前Square员工创建的，目的是通过让发现和储存新产品变得更容易，帮助夫妻店与亚马逊竞争。一个关键的好处是，它接受60天内没有售出的商品的免费退货，降低了零售商购买新库存时的风险。它还允许零售商搜索环保、手工或不在亚马逊上出售的商品。
疫情最初迫使该平台上的大多数商店关门，导致库存订单暴跌超过60%，并导致超过一半的零售客户警告称，他们可能在三个月后关门。作为回应，Fire为购买了库存的零售商延长了支付条件，并免除了向品牌收取的费用，以便立即获得订单付款。它还增加了需求旺盛的产品，如口罩、清洁用品和食品，并举办了有史以来第一次在线贸易展，让零售商在假日季节之前很容易获得打折库存。
Fire的联合创始人兼首席执行官马克斯·罗兹(Max Rhodes)表示，从5月下旬开始，随着封锁的放松，平台上的小企业开始看到销售反弹，作为一个整体，现在大致持平于一年前的水平。
罗兹说：“来自社区的支持源源不断，人们现在都在不厌其烦地在当地购物，因为他们认识到自己对社区有多么重要，并希望确保自己度过真正困难的一年。”
他说，费尔的业务在过去12个月里增长了两倍多，客户数量翻了一番，在其市场上购买了超过3500万件产品，在高峰期一天内转移了多达400万美元的库存。Fire现在向10万多家当地零售商提供从1万个品牌到10万多家当地零售商的产品，并吹嘘其零售合作伙伴网络在北美的门店数量比星巴克、沃尔格林、沃尔玛、丝芙兰、塔吉特和诺德斯特龙的总和还要多。
它计划利用筹集的资金进一步扩大国际业务，明年进入英国，不久之后进入其他欧洲国家。该公司还将寻求扩大客户基础，专注于吸引拥有5至10家门店的较大零售商和服装零售商，并为其四个办事处招聘更多员工。
红杉资本(Sequoia)合伙人、Insta前首席财务官拉维·古普塔(Ravi Gupta)表示：“我们认为当地零售业前景广阔，但它正在发生变化。”“我认为，FIRE更加注重数据驱动，更具活力和全方位，有助于将当地零售商带入未来。”
在临时关闭门店后，许多小型零售商今年首次开始投资于他们的网站和社交媒体业务，并提供新的送货选择，并试验直播和其他新技术。为了帮助他们管理目前在网上和商店出售的库存，Fire推出了与Square和Shopify的整合，并继续为它认为会卖得特别好的商品提供产品推荐。该公司试点的一个名为Shop Neighborhood的网站允许消费者在网上购买几个社区小企业的商品，由于该公司希望将资源重新引导回核心业务，该网站本周被关闭。
Fire仍然看到了巨大的机遇：根据美国小企业管理局(Small Business Administration And Fire)的数据，仅在美国，就有超过260万家独立零售商创造了近1万亿美元的年销售额。“最棒的是，费尔才刚刚开始。它最终可能会服务于数百万的零售商和数十万个品牌，“古普塔说。

Faire has completed a $170 million Series E round led by Sequoia Capital that more than doubled the valuation of the online wholesaler to $2.5 billion, as the San Francisco-based startup cashes in on pandemic shopping patterns by helping small businesses stock up on in-demand items.
  Bloomberg first  reported the round last week, saying the company was in talks to raise more than $100 million at a valuation of over $2 billion. Existing investors including Y Combinator, Lightspeed Venture Partners, Forerunner Ventures, Khosla Ventures and Founders Fund participated in the round and were joined by new investors DST Global, D1 Capital Partners, Norwest Venture Partners and Dragoneer. Faire has raised a total of $439 million since it was founded in 2017.
 The wholesale marketplace was created by three former Square employees to help mom-and-pop stores compete against Amazon by making it easier to discover and stock new products. A key benefit is that it accepts free returns within 60 days for items that don’t sell, reducing the risk a retailer runs when buying new inventory. It also allows retailers to search for items that are environmentally friendly, handmade or not sold on Amazon.
 The pandemic initially forced the majority of stores on the platform to shut their doors, sending inventory orders plunging by  more than 60% and leading more than half of its retail customers to warn they could be out of business in three months. In response, Faire offered extensions on its payment terms for retailers who had purchased inventory and waived the fees it charges brands to get paid for orders right away. It also added products in high demand, like masks, cleaning supplies and food, and held its first-ever online trade show, giving retailers easy access to discounted inventory ahead of the holiday season.
 Starting in late May, with lockdowns loosening, the small businesses on the platform began to see sales rebound and, as a group, are now roughly flat to where they were a year ago, says Max Rhodes, cofounder and CEO of Faire.
 “There has been an outpouring of support from communities and people are going out of their way to shop local right now because they recognize how important they are to the communities and want to make sure they get through what has been a really difficult year,” Rhodes says.
 He says Faire’s business has more than tripled in the last 12 months and its customer based doubled, purchasing more than 35 million products on its marketplace and moving as much as $4 million in inventory in a single day during peak times. Faire now offers products from 10,000 brands to more than 100,000 local retailers and boasts that its network of retail partners has more store locations in North America than Starbucks, Walgreens, Walmart, Sephora, Target and Nordstrom combined.
  It plans to use the capital raised to expand further internationally, entering the United Kingdom next year and other European countries shortly thereafter. It will also look to expand its customer base with a focus on attracting larger retailers with five to 10 locations and apparel retailers, and to hire more staff for its four offices.
 “We think local retail has a tremendous future, but it’s changing,” says Ravi Gupta, a partner at Sequoia and Instacart’s former chief financial officer. “I think Faire helps bring local retailers into the future by being more data-driven, dynamic and omnichannel.”
 Many small retailers began investing in their websites and social media presence for the first time this year in the wake of temporary store closures, as well as offering new delivery options and experimenting with livestreaming and other new technologies. To help them manage inventory now sold online and in stores, Faire launched integrations with Square and Shopify and continued to make product recommendations for items it thinks will sell particularly well. A website it piloted called Shop Neighborhood that allowed consumers to shop online for items from small businesses in several communities was shuttered this week as the company looked to redirect resources back into the core business.
 Faire still sees massive opportunity ahead: There are more than 2.6 million independent retailers generating almost $1 trillion in annual sales in the U.S. alone, according to the Small Business Administration and Faire. “The best part of this is Faire is just getting started. It may ultimately serve millions of retailers and hundreds of thousands of brands,” says Gupta.

编剧指导罗伯特·麦基(Robert McKee)前几天在列克星敦大道(Lexington Avenue)一家黑暗的爱尔兰酒吧后面吃午饭。他刚刚在亨特学院(Hunter College)的一个报告厅里告诉200人，如果没有五个要素，一部惊悚片可能就不是惊悚片：廉价的惊喜；虚假的结局；被证明是受害者的主人公；赞扬恶棍的演讲；以及任由恶棍摆布的英雄场景。然后，他宣布休息一小时，走出教室，下着小雨，后面跟着一些学生，他们对课外麦基的渴望超过了他们对他可能会以某种方式羞辱他们的担忧，就像众所周知的他所做的那样。他们在人行道上拦住了他，就像尼古拉斯·凯奇(Nicolas Cage)在斯派克·琼兹(Spike Jonze)2002年的电影“改编”(Adaption)中扮演陷入困境的编剧查理·考夫曼(Charlie Kaufman)一样，拦住了饰演罗伯特·麦基(Robert McKee)的。(考夫曼自我介绍说，“你今天早上对他大喊大叫的那个家伙。”麦基回答说：“我需要更多。”
麦基现年62岁，他喜欢穿领口两颗纽扣没有扣的深色衬衫，这表明他从事过敲诈勒索的职业。他点燃了一支香烟，然后走在街上，听一个焦躁的年轻人说，他最后一次听麦基演讲时，效果是如此压倒性，以至于他生病了。“所有你不想面对的东西，也就是说情感上的真相，好的讲故事的东西，都出来了！”年轻人说，非常快。“它出来的方式让我背部疼痛，因为潜意识的成长是一个非常痛苦的过程。”学生们一个接一个地离开，直到麦基到达几个街区外的酒吧时，只剩下两个。他请他们和他一起坐在一个摊位上，在那里他点了一份火腿奶酪三明治和一杯啤酒。
他的客人都是三十多岁。一位从事医疗保险工作的人说，作为一个“有抱负的编剧”，在十年的时间里，他没有完成一个剧本。他上过三次麦基课程，还多次读过麦基1997年出版的书“故事”(Story)。“我开始怀疑我是否对整个过程有耐心，”他说。麦基看着他。“嗯，你可能也想知道你是否有这个天赋，”他说。麦基曾经是一名演员，他几乎没有一句话不需要一个词来强调，以至于他露出了牙齿。
另一名学生名叫史蒂文·李斯特(Steven List)，他说他已经卖出了一个剧本和三个剧本，但他正在努力创作另一个根据真实事件改编的剧本。正如李斯特所描述的那样，20世纪80年代，一位美国数学家在智利度假时失踪。国务院曾告诉他的家人，他是在徒步旅行时溺水身亡的，但他的妹妹不相信。她飞往智利，在那里她了解到，她的兄弟可能被绑架并关押在一个偏远的宗教殖民地，领头的是一名富有魅力的新纳粹分子，他曾作为智利秘密警察的酷刑和暗杀分包商工作-这一安排据说对华盛顿来说很熟悉。李斯特从这位姐姐那里选择了这篇报道。麦基通常有一条规则，不允许讨论学生正在进行的作业，但他允许清单继续。
李斯特说：“从这位兄弟的角度来看，我可以这么做，但他最终还是死了。”“我抓到了一个恶棍。我知道有个故事。“。
“你没有故事，”麦基用吸烟者的咆哮说。“你有一个主题：这个怪异的后纳粹邪教世界。但谁在乎呢？“。
“不，不，事实是：谁在乎呢？你所拥有的是一个场景，一段历史。你得问些大问题。“为什么我会被这种材料所吸引？”因为我是犹太人，我想再抓一次那些纳粹分子？“。我的建议是不要把注意力集中在这一个人身上。我不认为那条路的尽头有任何东西。“。
编剧考虑了他的选择。“我必须找到一根脊梁，一个主人公。我一直在想，妹妹。。.“
“那部电影已经拍完了，叫做‘失踪’，”麦基说。“为什么要报道一个身处险境的女人？你有一个组织与智利政府勾结，与美国政府勾结，导致数千人死亡-酷刑，痛苦等等-结果我们让一名妇女处于危险之中？这就像雇一头大象拉着一辆红色的小马车。我可以给你讲一个处于危险之中的女人的故事：她半夜车胎爆了，有人让她搭便车。“。他接着说，“这里有趣的是，这是美国习惯性地迁就暴君的一个例子，只要他们是我们的盟友。”
List向前倾过桌子说，“这就是我感兴趣的！我们保护了怪物！“。在李斯特的故事中，我们似乎正在接近麦基所说的“煽动事件”：事情即将改变。
“所以从一个华盛顿的官僚开始，他为中情局以外的机构工作，”麦基说。“突然冒出一件事，一名失踪的教授。”他停顿了一下。“按照英国的传统，谋杀发生后，调查就会深入：你知道，你有六个可能的凶手。在美国的传统中，谋杀案发生后，我们开始调查，结果发现它涵盖了整个社会。你的东西听起来就是这样的。一张无伤大雅的便条说，一位教授在安第斯山脉徒步旅行时失踪，一些小官僚负责查明发生了什么，他发现了一个阴谋，这个阴谋延伸到了白宫。这是‘视差景观’。“。
一个小时后，回到演讲室，List仍然热情地嗡嗡作响：“你知道，我已经和很多工作室讨论过这个项目，他们都没有看过--他在五分钟内就发现了。哦，那真是太棒了。“。
编剧指导是一个变革性的行业：学生们在那里学习电影主人公在两个小时的电影中经历变化的方式(从愚蠢到聪明，从没有人到某人，从官僚到举报人)；他们还了解在他们能够塑造这样一个人物之前可能必须经历的变化。当一位制片厂负责人被他主动编写的剧本迷住时，学生们可能也会感觉到他们生活中即将发生的变化，并希望他立即结束自己在高中历史教学方面的生活，开始自己的职业生涯，专注于穿着昂贵的运动裤在马里布的豪宅里漫步，同时一团团皱巴巴的黄色法律文件在温暖的微风中漂浮在露台上。成人教育的其他分支的力量可能类似，但可能会更弱：参加编剧研讨会的学生正在学习如何在页面上创造一个关于奋斗和决心的故事，至少看起来像是呼应了编剧生活中的挣扎和希望的决心。这部作品承诺加速它经常代表的行动，这是一种重新绘制的生活-一位明星，以某种方式出生。因此，很容易理解为什么一个有效的编剧教练可以成为他的学生生活中的霸道人物，为什么麦基比任何讲授畜牧学课程的人都更经常地被称为“大师”。
麦基自己的生活几乎不受编剧成功的影响。他创作和销售了许多剧本，但如果不包括1994年特纳网络电视台委托制作的“亚伯拉罕”，那么这些剧本都没有被拍成电影。麦基在贝莱尔和亚利桑那州都有房子，有一辆英俊的黑色美洲豹，在盖蒂博物馆(Getty Museum)以北的一个乡村俱乐部里有会员，但这些主要是相当平淡无奇的重复生活的好处：麦基20年来一直在教授同样的剧本课程-同样的三天三十小时的表演，在此期间，他扮演着饭后喋喋不休的人，忧郁的争议家，以及随心所欲的跨学科大学讲师的角色。在大约4万名参加过课程的人中，有大卫·鲍伊、埃德·伯恩斯、德鲁·凯里(两次)、约翰·克利斯(三次)、柯克·道格拉斯、费伊·达纳韦、埃米利奥·埃斯特维斯、埃迪·伊扎德、昆西·琼斯(三次)、黛安·基顿、巴里·马尼洛、琼·里弗斯、朱莉娅·罗伯茨、梅格·瑞安、乔尔·舒马赫、布鲁克·希尔兹和格洛丽亚·斯泰纳姆。麦基小心翼翼地不直接归功于他，但他最近估计，他的校友的电影在过去一年左右的时间里获得了超过10亿美元的票房：他想到的是安德鲁·斯坦顿(Andrew Stanton)(编剧并联合导演了《海底总动员》)、彼得·杰克逊(Peter Jackson)(他是《指环王：双塔》(Lord Of The Rings：The Two Towers)的联合编剧和导演)、史蒂夫·科伦(Steve Korn)(他是《全能的布鲁斯》的联合编剧)和扎克·潘(Zak Penn)(他为《X2》写了故事)。在麦基的宣传文学中，威廉·戈德曼称他“知识渊博、充满激情”；劳伦斯·卡斯丹将麦基的课程描述为“激动人心的、应对古老挑战的创新方法”；而阿基瓦·戈德斯曼则称自己为“一个信徒”。
这一流派的第一本现代畅销书是西德·菲尔德(Syd Field)的“剧本”。这本书于1979年首次出版，至今仍特别感谢“沃纳”和“所有穿着EST的人”，目前已印刷了50万册。“剧本”源于菲尔德在加利福尼亚州的一所私立学校舍伍德橡树实验学院教授的一门课程，该学院试图利用达斯汀·霍夫曼(Dustin Hoffman)和保罗·纽曼(Paul Newman)等活跃于该行业的人作为导师，“剧本”是一本薄薄、友好、乐观的书，有感叹号和一句话的段落。电影总是有开头、中间和结尾。从“剧本”开始，他们一共有三幕：第一幕是布景，第二幕是对抗，第三幕是决议。“情节要点”将故事从一幕转到另一幕。(根据菲尔德的说法，他教的是“只教形式，不教公式”，第二幕从第30页到第90页。)。菲尔德的语言深深扎根于好莱坞-这一事实让一些人感到疯狂，包括约翰·特鲁比(John Truby)，他是一名编剧教练，地位仅次于麦基和菲尔德。特鲁比教授研讨会，并推广一个名为“特鲁比的百视达”的计算机程序。他最近表示，他认为菲尔德的三幕思想是“完全肤浅对任何类型内容的胜利”。
麦基说他“没有竞争对手”，他把自己描绘成一个大胆、愤怒的知识分子，与菲尔德形成鲜明对比。“故事”在前几页赞扬了英格玛·伯格曼(Ingmar Bergman)，引用了叶芝(Yeats)和让·阿努伊尔(Jean Anouilh)的话；这本书只有精装本，在美国的销量超过10万册。麦基在看了包括迈克尔·凯恩(Michael Caine)、特伦斯·斯坦普(Terence Stamp)和克里斯托弗·普卢默(Christopher Plummer)在内的一系列名字后，选择了布莱恩·考克斯(Brian Cox)来扮演“改编”中的他；但有人猜测，他会对哈罗德·布鲁姆(Harold Bloom)最满意。“‘故事’是关于永恒的、普遍的形式，而不是公式，”麦基在他的书的开头写道，但对他来说，这种结构不仅仅是一种免责声明：它是他的平台。麦基展示了他自己的相对无能，因此--在一个快乐的悖论中--建立了他的智力力量。天生有才华的人会成功，其他人可能都会失败。生活是“苦差事和失望”，死亡潜伏在角落里。今年早些时候，当我在伦敦见到麦基的时候，也就是“故事”研讨会的前一天，他告诉我，“我教的是事实：你无法理解，这不是一种爱好，这是一种艺术形式，也是一种职业，你成功的机会非常非常渺茫。如果你只有一个故事，他妈的滚出去。作家是有故事要讲的人。我想我帮了很大的忙，把外行赶出了家门。令人惊讶的是，无论我多么努力地想把他们赶出艺术，我通过诚实获得的声誉把他们带到了球场上。他们知道我不是骗子，我不会向他们兜售梦想。“。
麦基在底特律北郊的克劳森长大；他的父亲是通用汽车的工程师，母亲在房地产工作。“我父亲在很多方面都是个了不起的人，”麦基告诉我。“他让我开始读书。他的标准很高。但他也是个偏执的酒鬼。“。麦基十六岁时，他的父亲离开了这个家庭。麦基说：“当我在做精神分析时，这很大程度上与我和父亲的关系有关。”“我的分析师说，任何人生活中的核心冲突都是与父亲的冲突，你正处于进退两难的境地：你想给你父亲留下深刻印象，但你无法超越他，因为如果你这样做了，即使他死了，也会让他感到羞辱。”麦基的母亲“想象力很丰富，但在很多方面都是个孩子。我十岁的时候，她来找我说，“鲍比，我该拿你父亲怎么办呢？”我在给她做心理咨询。“。麦基有两个小弟弟。一个人在中年去世，另一个成为福特的高级管理人员，现在已经退休，住在佛罗里达州。
麦基从12岁起就是一名高尔夫球童，他获得了密歇根大学的埃文斯奖学金(发给球童)。他喜欢从事牙科工作的想法，因为这似乎有空闲的时间打高尔夫球，但在得到一个学生话剧的角色后，他决定主修英语。他获得了戏剧硕士学位，师从已故的肯尼思·罗(Kenneth Rowe)，后者也曾教过阿瑟·米勒(Arthur Miller)。麦基成为一名戏剧演员和导演，先是在密歇根，然后在伦敦，然后在60年代末在纽约。与一位舞台艺人的第一次婚姻在八个月后结束。
麦基再婚，并于1970年回到安娜堡攻读电影研究博士学位。在那里，他和妻子有两个儿子，他制作了两部广受好评的短片-一部改编自田纳西·威廉姆斯(Tennessee Williams)的戏剧“像雨一样对我说话”(Talk To Me Like The Rain)，另一部来自他自己的剧本“休息一天”(A Day Off)，讲述了两个孤独的男人在一起度过尴尬而醉醺醺的一天的故事。他没有获得博士学位，没有完成一篇关于叙事设计的论文(几年后，穆

Robert McKee, the screenwriting instructor, was having lunch the other day at the back of a dark Irish bar on Lexington Avenue. He had just told two hundred people in a Hunter College lecture hall that there were five elements without which a thriller was probably not a thriller: cheap surprise; a false ending; the protagonist shown to be a victim; a speech made in praise of the villain; and a hero-at-the-mercy-of-the-villain scene. Then, announcing a one-hour break, he had walked out into a light rain, followed by a number of students whose desire for a little extracurricular McKee outstripped their fear that he might somehow humiliate them, as he has been known to do. They waylaid him on the sidewalk, the way Nicolas Cage, playing the troubled screenwriter Charlie Kaufman, waylaid Brian Cox, playing Robert McKee, in Spike Jonze’s 2002 film, “Adaptation.” (Kaufman introduces himself as “the guy you yelled at this morning.” McKee responds, “I need more.”)
 McKee, who is sixty-two, and likes to wear dark shirts with two buttons undone at the neck, suggesting a career in extortion, lit a cigarette, then walked down the street while listening to an agitated young man say that the last time he had heard McKee speak the effect had been so overwhelming that he had fallen ill. “All the stuff you don’t want to face, which is to say emotional truth, the stuff of good storytelling, it was coming out!” the young man said, very fast. “It was coming out in such a way that it caused this pain in my back, because subconscious growth is such a painful process.” One by one, the students dropped away, until, by the time McKee reached the bar, a few blocks away, only two were left. He asked them to join him in a booth, where he ordered a ham-and-cheese sandwich and a beer.
 His guests were in their thirties. One worked in health insurance, and said that in ten years as “an aspiring screenwriter” he had not managed to finish a single script. He had taken a McKee course three times, and he had read McKee’s 1997 book, “Story,” many more times. “I’m starting to wonder if I have the patience for the whole process,” he said. McKee looked at him. “Well, you might also wonder if you have the  talent,” he said. McKee, who used to be an actor, rarely speaks a sentence that does not call for a word so stressed that he bares his teeth.
  The other student, whose name was Steven List, said he had already sold a script and three pitches but he was struggling with another screenplay, which was based on true events. As List described it, an American mathematician had disappeared while on vacation in Chile in the nineteen-eighties. The State Department had told his family that he had drowned while hiking, but his sister did not believe it. She flew to Chile, where she learned that her brother may have been abducted and held in a remote religious colony led by a charismatic neo-Nazi who worked for the Chilean secret police as a subcontractor in torture and assassination—an arrangement supposedly well known to Washington. List had optioned this story from the sister. McKee usually has a rule against discussing a student’s work in progress, but he allowed List to continue.
 “I could do it from the brother’s point of view, but he ends up dead, ” List said. “I’ve got a villain. I know there’s a story.”
 “You don’t have a story,” McKee said in a smoker’s growl. “You have a subject matter: this bizarre post-Nazi cult world. But who cares?”
   “No, no, the truth of the matter is: Who cares? What you’ve got is a setting, and a piece of history. You’ve got to ask big questions. ‘Why am I attracted to this material? Because I’m Jewish and I want to get at those Nazis one more time?’ My advice is stop focussing on this one guy. I don’t think there’s anything at the end of that road. ”
  The screenwriter considered his choices. “I’ve got to find a spine, a protagonist. I’ve been thinking, the sister . . .”
 “That film’s been done, and it’s called ‘Missing,’ ” McKee said. “Why do a woman-in-jeopardy story? You’ve got an organization in cahoots with the Chilean government, in cahoots with the United States government, which has caused the death of thousands—torture, suffering, etc.—and as a result we’ve got a woman in jeopardy? It’s like hiring an elephant to pull a little red wagon. I can tell you a woman-in-jeopardy story: she gets a flat tire in the middle of the night, some guy offers her a lift.” He went on, “What is interesting here is it’s an example of the way the United States has habitually accommodated tyrants as long as they’re our allies.”
 List leaned forward across the table and said, “That’s what I’m interested in! We’ve protected monsters!” In the story of List’s story, we seemed to be approaching what McKee calls an “inciting incident”: things were about to change.
  “So start with a guy who’s a bureaucrat in Washington, works for something other than the C.I.A.,” McKee said. “Something pops up, a missing professor.” He paused. “In the English tradition, a murder is committed and the investigation drives inward: you know, you’ve got six possible murderers. In the American tradition, a murder is committed, we start to investigate, and it turns out to encompass all of society. That’s what your thing sounds like. An innocuous note saying that a professor has disappeared while hiking in the Andes, and some little bureaucrat is charged with finding out what happened, and he finds a conspiracy that runs to the White House. It’s ‘The Parallax View.’ ”
  An hour later, back in the lecture room, List was still buzzing with enthusiasm: “You know, I’ve talked about this project with any number of studios, and they didn’t see it—and he spotted it in five minutes. Oh, that was extraordinary.”
  Screenwriting instruction is a transformative business: students are there to learn about the way a protagonist undergoes change in the two hours of a movie (dumb to smart, nobody to somebody, bureaucrat to whistle-blower); and they learn about the change they may have to undergo before they are able to create such a character. And students may also get a sense of the change to come in their lives when word reaches one of them that a studio chief was charmed by his unsolicited script, and would like him immediately to bring to a close his life in, say, high-school history teaching and start a career focussed on ambling around a Malibu mansion wearing expensive track pants while balls of scrunched-up yellow legal paper drift across the patio in a warm breeze. The forces at work in other branches of adult education may be similar but are likely to be weaker: students at a screenwriting seminar are learning how to create, on the page, a story of struggle and resolution that at least appears to echo the struggle and hoped-for resolution of the screenwriting life. The work promises to precipitate the action it often represents, which is a life redrawn—a star, one way or another, being born. So it’s easy to see why an effective screenwriting instructor could become a commanding figure in the life of his students, and why McKee is more frequently referred to as a “guru” than anyone giving classes in animal husbandry.
 McKee himself leads a life mostly unaffected by screenwriting success. He has written and sold many screenplays, but, if one excludes “Abraham,” commissioned by Turner Network Television in 1994, none of them have been made into a movie. McKee has houses in Bel Air and Arizona, and a handsome black Jaguar, and membership in a country club just north of the Getty Museum, but these are mostly the benefits of a rather uncinematic life of repetition: McKee has given the same screenplay course for twenty years—the same three-day, thirty-hour performance during which he assumes, variously, the roles of after-dinner raconteur, gloomy controversialist, and freewheeling, cross-disciplinary university lecturer. Among the estimated forty thousand people who have taken the course are David Bowie, Ed Burns, Drew Carey (twice), John Cleese (three times), Kirk Douglas, Faye Dunaway, Emilio Estevez, Eddie Izzard, Quincy Jones (three times), Diane Keaton, Barry Manilow, Joan Rivers, Julia Roberts, Meg Ryan, Joel Schumacher, Brooke Shields, and Gloria Steinem. McKee is careful not to take direct credit, but he recently estimated that his alumni’s films have earned more than a billion dollars at the box office in the past year or so: he was thinking of the work of Andrew Stanton (who wrote and co-directed “Finding Nemo”), Peter Jackson (who co-wrote and directed “Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers”), Steve Koren (who co-wrote “Bruce Almighty”), and Zak Penn (who co-wrote the story for “X2”). In McKee’s promotional literature William Goldman calls him “knowledgeable and passionate”; Lawrence Kasdan describes McKee’s course as “stimulating, an innovative approach to the age-old challenge”; and Akiva Goldsman calls himself “a believer.” Pixar sends ten people to every McKee seminar in San Francisco; Miramax sent five or six to New York in 2001. Antonia Ellis, a producer of “Sex and the City,” lists McKee’s course as “additional post-graduate course work” on her HBO biography. Last year, McKee gave his three-day seminar twice in Los Angeles, New York, and London, and once in Boston, San Francisco, Miami, Dallas, Las Vegas, Sydney, Melbourne, and Paris. This year, he made his first appearance in Singapore, where he was asked not to use the word “fuck” onstage, and in November he will teach in Pamplona. McKee has given a private, truncated version of his course for ABC News. He has been hired to teach C.E.O.s the commercial virtues of telling a compelling (rather than a blindly upbeat) story of a corporation’s life. He has been invited to make a presentation to  . Recently, for senior members of an Arizona-based church, he adapted the seminar as “The Glory of Story.”
  Before the arrival of cinema, there were how-to guides for aspiring novelists and playwrights. Then, when movies appeared, so did books like “How to Write Moving Picture Plays,” by William Lewis Gordon (1913), and “How to Write a Photoplay,” by A. W. Thomas (1914). Thomas nodded to Aristotle (as most modern guides do), and used the kind of subheadings—“Modeling the Dramatic,” “Hiding the Climax”—that seem to call out for PowerPoint software. According to Gordon, “in practically every story there should be an element of rivalry with one or more obstacles to overcome.” He steered his readers away from children, animals, autobiographical stories, Westerns, expensive military plots, and slapstick. “   ,” he wrote, exactly anticipating the spirit (and uppercase letters) of his modern successors.
 Today, a fair-sized Barnes & Noble will carry about sixty books in a similar vein, including “Aristotle’s Poetics for Screenwriters: Storytelling Secrets from the Greatest Mind in Western Civilization.” Most are alert to the obvious booby trap in the how-to-write genre: the author has not written a hit screenplay, and so offers guidance only in general structural principles—a form, not a formula. All the same, many of these books—and their accompanying courses and software packages—find it hard to resist dropping a number into the title, to hint that science will take charge of the slippery mess of words on a page: “How Not to Write a Screenplay: 101 Common Mistakes Most Screenwriters Make”; “500 Ways to Beat the Hollywood Script Reader: Writing the Screenplay the Reader Will Recommend”; “Power Screenwriting: The 12 Stages of Story Development.” In “How to Write a Movie in 21 Days,” Viki King explains that “by page 45, your hero has reacted to what happened on page 30. He is now different, and we begin to see that here, in a symbolic scene. Also, by page 45 we begin to see a resolution of the original desire your character had on page 10.”
  The first modern best-seller in the genre was “Screenplay,” by Syd Field. First published in 1979, the book still carries a special thanks to “Werner” and “all the people in  est,” and half a million copies have been printed. Derived from a course that Field taught at Sherwood Oaks Experimental College, a private school in California that sought to use people active in the industry as instructors, including Dustin Hoffman and Paul Newman, “Screenplay” is a slim, friendly, upbeat book, with exclamation points and one-sentence paragraphs. Movies had always had beginnings, middles, and ends. Since “Screenplay,” they have had three acts: Act I is the setup; Act II is the confrontation; and Act III is the resolution. “Plot points” spin the story around, from act to act. (According to Field, who argues that he is teaching “only form, not formula,” the second act runs from page 30 to page 90.) Field’s language burrowed deep into Hollywood—a fact that some find maddening, including John Truby, a screenwriting instructor with a standing just below that of McKee and Field. Truby, who teaches seminars and markets a computer program called “Truby’s Blockbuster,” recently said that he regarded Field’s three-act idea to be “the triumph of complete superficiality over any type of content.”
 McKee, who says he has “no competition,” presents himself in contrast to Field as a bold, angry intellectual. “Story,” in its first few pages, praises Ingmar Bergman and quotes from Yeats and Jean Anouilh; the book has only ever been available in a hardback edition, which has sold more than a hundred thousand copies in the United States. McKee chose Brian Cox to play him in “Adaptation,” after looking over a list of names that included Michael Caine, Terence Stamp, and Christopher Plummer; but one guesses that he would have been most pleased with Harold Bloom. “ ‘Story’ is about eternal, universal forms, not formulas,” McKee writes at the start of his book, but for him this construction becomes more than a disclaimer: it is his platform. McKee displays his own relative impotence, and so—in a happy paradox—establishes his intellectual force. Those born with talent will succeed, every one else will probably fail. Life is “drudgery and disappointment”; and death lurks around the corner. When I met McKee in London earlier this year, the day before a “Story” seminar, he told me, “What I teach is the truth: you’re in over your head, this is not a hobby, this is an art form and a profession, and your chances of success are very, very slim. And if you’ve got only one story, get the fuck out of here. Writers are people with stories to tell. I think I do a great service, by sending the dilettantes out of the door. The amazing thing is that, no matter how hard I try to drive them out of the art, the reputation I’ve gained by being honest brings them to the course. They know I’m not a phony, I’m not selling them a dream.”
  McKee grew up in Clawson, a northern suburb of Detroit; his father was an engineer at General Motors and his mother worked in real estate. “My father was in many ways a marvellous guy,” McKee told me. “He got me into reading. He had high standards. But he was also a paranoid alcoholic.” McKee was sixteen when his father left the family. “When I was in psychoanalysis, it was a lot to do with my relationship with my father,” McKee said. “And my analyst said that the central conflict in any man’s life is with his father, and you’re in a dilemma: you want to impress your father, but you cannot surpass him, because if you do, it humiliates him, even if he’s dead.” McKee’s mother “had a great imagination, but in many ways was a child. When I was ten, she came to me and said, ‘Bobby, what shall I do about your father?’ I was counselling her.” McKee had two younger bothers. One died in middle age; the other became a senior Ford executive, and has now retired and lives in Florida.
 McKee was a golf caddie from the age of twelve, and he won an Evans scholarship (given to caddies) to the University of Michigan. He had liked the idea of a career in dentistry, because of the free time for golfing it seemed to promise, but, after being given a part in a student play, he decided to major in English. He took a master’s in theatre, and was taught by the late Kenneth Rowe, who had also taught Arthur Miller. McKee became a theatre actor and a director, first in Michigan, then in London, and then, in the late sixties, in New York. A first marriage, to a stage entertainer, ended after eight months.
 McKee remarried and returned to Ann Arbor in 1970 to pursue a Ph.D. in film studies. There, he and his wife had two sons, and he made two well-received short films—one an adaptation of a Tennessee Williams play, “Talk to Me Like the Rain,” and the other from his own screenplay, “A Day Off,” about two lonely men spending an awkward, drunken day together. He did not receive his Ph.D., failing to finish a dissertation on narrative design (years later, much of it emerged as “Story”); instead, McKee took a teaching job at San Diego State University, and wrote the first of his screenplays, “Dead Files,” about a hired assassin who seeks psychiatric help when he discovers that he can no longer kill. He sold it to  -Embassy Films in 1976, but, in the first of many such disappointments, the company changed hands, and the project was dropped. “You get your heart broken again and again and again,” McKee told me. He took work as a story analyst for NBC and United Artists, and also began writing episodes for television dramas. He directed “Greeks 6-Trojans 5,” a play set entirely in the body of the Trojan horse, and wrote “Miss Julie Montgomery,” a screenplay that recast Strindberg’s “Miss Julie” as an interracial period love story set in the South; it has been optioned four times and never made—although last summer McKee was pleased to see that it was optioned again, twenty years after it was written. (He showed me the script, which in places has a miniseries feel to it, as when Julie’s father says, “And old times here are not forgotten. . . . If all goes well today, I’ll be changing times . . . from the governor’s mansion.”) McKee’s other scripts are “all dead,” he said. A career was visible but just out of reach. “Of course you mind,” he told me with a slight sneer. But he consoles himself with the thought of the odds against him—only one in twenty scripts optioned ever gets made—and the amount of money that some of his unmade films earned him. He told me, “Warner Bros. said, ‘Bob, we want “Jagged Edge” goes rock and roll for Cher.’ I wrote a thing called ‘Trophy,’ for an embarrassing amount of money, about a rock star who murders a husband and gets away with it. They loved it. Loved it.” But apparently Cher did not.
 In 1981, McKee began teaching a course called “Story Structure” at Sherwood Oaks. His audiences grew, and in 1983 Jeff Dowd, who later became a key figure in the world of American independent film, and the Coen brothers’ chief inspiration for the character of Jeff Lebowski in “The Big Lebowski,” asked McKee to teach a compressed, three-day version in Seattle. It was with this gruelling format that McKee began travelling the country, and the world. (After his second marriage failed, he lived for several years in Britain, in a remote spot on the Cornish coast.) McKee became part of a great boom in screenwriting instruction which had its roots in the end of the studio system and the subsequent rise of the American auteur director: a screenwriter being one step from a director, and a director being God. The boom was further propelled by public knowledge of the multimillion-dollar fees paid to writers like Joe Eszterhas and Shane Black. Screenwriting began to look like the weak point in a wall standing between the people in the land of joy and self-fulfillment and the people outside, a perception that led, in time, to such courses as “The Magic of the Midpoint,” which is being offered this month at Screenwriting Expo 2, a carnival for aspiring screenwriters, in Los Angeles.

上个月，美国联邦当局起诉了六名电商顾问和亚马逊前员工，他们涉嫌参与了一项1亿美元的贿赂计划，其中内部人士涉嫌收受付款，以帮助平台上的某些亚马逊商家，并伤害其他人。在亚马逊顶级卖家和顾问组成的紧密联系的世界里，这是一条大新闻。但这并不令人惊讶。关于这种行为的传言在行业圈子里很常见，亚马逊本身在2018年承认，它正在调查员工，据报道，这些员工向外部泄露内部市场数据，以换取现金。
在起诉书提出后的几周里，六名收入最高的亚马逊卖家告诉Recode，如果被起诉的顾问和前员工违反了法律，他们应该面临法律后果。但这些销量最高的卖家也认为，问题远比几个坏苹果大得多，亚马逊为贿赂计划的开花结果创造了肥沃的土壤，值得审查。原因呢？亚马逊没有能力或拒绝在170万卖家出现问题时持续向他们提供足够的支持，特别是当涉及到暂停时，亚马逊几乎没有解释，有时甚至没有警告。除了这些问题，卖家在亚马逊的炼狱里苦苦挣扎数周或数月，试图恢复业务的情况并不少见，要么是自己，要么是在顾问生态系统的帮助下-其中一些顾问利用商家的绝望。

这一现实-亚马逊卖家随时可能被夺走他们的生计-也可以让亚马逊受益。该公司在2018年推出了一项高端卖家计划，每月收取数千美元的费用，指派一名卖家可以轻松联系的专职亚马逊代表。虽然这些代表不监督账户暂停，也不能直接恢复商家，但亚马逊的一些大型卖家支付这笔费用主要是为了在被暂停或其他严厉处罚的情况下有一个可以联系到的人。
亚马逊经常吹嘘，帮助进货Everything Store虚拟货架的中小型商家占该公司全球电子商务销售额的60%。该公司强调了这一点，因为该公司对待卖家的方式在过去几年里一直受到审查，最近一次是在杰夫·贝佐斯(Jeff Bezos)7月份在国会作证期间，以及随后发布的众议院反垄断调查报告之后。这家科技巨头肯定为小商家创造了一种高效的方式，用小团队和很少的管理费用建立全球电子商务业务，这种方式在10年前也是不可能的。与此同时，随着亚马逊在其平台上积极招募更多卖家，对其提供的支持的抱怨也一直困扰着亚马逊-最引人注目的是，该公司倾向于在没有警告和解释的情况下暂停卖家在网站上做生意。
这就是背包品牌State Baks的联合创始人杰奎琳·塔特尔曼(Jacqueline Tatelman)今年早些时候面临的情况。她的创业品牌大部分业务都是通过自己的网站进行的，但今年早些时候决定开始在亚马逊上销售，以便在今年秋天返校购物季之前扩大在线业务。当3月份大流行袭击美国时，该公司的计划被推迟，亚马逊在其仓库中优先考虑必需品。然后，当该公司准备终于在5月份开始在该平台上销售时，来自亚马逊的一封令人震惊的电子邮件进入了它的收件箱：
“我们发现了一些信息，表明您的亚马逊卖家帐户参与了欺骗性、欺诈性或非法活动。..。因此，我们已关闭您的亚马逊卖家帐户，以防止对我们的客户、其他销售合作伙伴和我们的商店造成伤害。“。
这封电子邮件的结尾说，如果该品牌认为这一决定是错误的，他们应该给亚马逊发电子邮件。而州级包就是这样做的，反复这样做。在该公司设立亚马逊店面到收到暂停通知之间，唯一发生变化的是更改了备案的商业信用卡，这是亚马逊要求的信息。
亚马逊再次做出回应，发布了一份通用说明，称内部案件已经开庭。然后沉默了几个月。没有给出原因，也没有更新，因为零售价值6万美元的State Baks库存在亚马逊的仓库里没有售出，这家科技巨头也没有就该品牌是否或如何拿出库存提供指导。
“在海洋中央，在暴风雨中，用一艘小船和一把坏了的船桨，对这些小品牌做这些事情在道德上是不正常的。”
Tatelman告诉Recode：“在海洋中央，在暴风雨中，用一艘小船和折断的船桨对这些小品牌做这些事情，在道德上是不正常的。”“这就是小品牌的感受。”

而且国家包袱的故事也不是一次性的。与任何在亚马逊网站上做着重要生意的亚马逊卖家交谈，他们很有可能也有类似的故事，或者认识一个有类似经历的同龄人。就在今年8月，一家汽车仪表盘摄像头零售商的创始人在LinkedIn上发布了一篇详细描述类似暂停问题的帖子，在亚马逊卖家社区中被广泛阅读。标题是“请帮帮我！在致杰夫·贝佐斯(Jeff Bezos)、亚马逊领导层和卖家表现团队的一封公开信中，“它描述了亚马逊是如何不知何故将卖家停职的，并声称卖家伪造了文件。在Dashcam商店总裁安德鲁·阿博达乌德(Andrew Aboudaoud)发布这一警示故事两天后，亚马逊通过一封样板电子邮件恢复了他的销售账户。没有给出任何解释或道歉。

亚马逊的卖家承认，将卖家支持扩展到亚马逊的规模是一个挑战，一些人说，近年来卖家支持体验略有改善。
“他们做得更好了，也更有说明性，但还有很长的路要走。”
